The bald man goes into the office and comes out in less than ten seconds and says,  “Your bags here are the only ones that will go through security today and be scanned, so let’s hurry and get out of here.”  As they leave, they see their bags are still in the line.  The Baldy Man starts to say something but is interrupted by two uniformed officers with guns drawn.  He says, “Excuse me, sir, could you possibly step out of the line, please?”  The man replies by saying, “Excuse the hell out of here!”  The officers remove the man from the line.  They search his bags, and find nothing incriminating. They take him to an interrogation room and ask him why he is trying to leave the country.  The man tells the officers that he has Alzheimer’s and is going on a business trip.  The man tells them that some members of his family were killed in a car accident.  He says that he is going to leave the country to find these victims.  Both the man and the officers are surprised to find that they actually have a lot in common.  The bald man asks the officer if he is planning on going anywhere on the trip.  The officer says in his quiet, hard voice, “I’ll stay here and wait for the rest of the world to start acting like men.”  The bald man replies, “I”m staying right here, thank you!”

That's what I'd say.

In her first year in college, Amy is pregnant as her father is away at war. He gets word of how far along Amy is and leaves with the car they are renting to send money to Amy so she can continue. While Amy waits in the parking lot to check in, she sees her mom pick up an older looking man. He tells Amy that he knows that her father is at war and that his brother has been killed. After that he just says that his mother told him about it and that it was his fault. Amy had no time to question what he said. The man tells her that he has taken the car and is heading to her college dormitory for whatever she needs. Amy sees her father in the parking lot, and her mother yells at him, "I know what you did!" "I'm not that stupid!" he responds. Amy's mother also says that she will not let her marry this man while her father is still away at war. After all of this, Amy's father arrives and tells her that she is pregnant. She says that the car is in the store and he has the number to their place so she can pick it up at their place.

Input: The first thing that was on Mark’s mind when he arrived home was a birthday party for his brother.  His brother’s b-day is on the 8th of December and if they did not celebrate before this, it would be 2 weeks to the b-day.  His uncle was in a job interview and Mark's brother had to stay at home because he was to late to fly in.  Mark had thought about celebrating early, but the thought of him going to work still did not sit too well.  He decided that the family should celebrate at dinner.  The meal that Mark prepared was as follows - turkey, beans and a salad with vegetables.  It was a complete meal that consisted of not a lot but at the same time, it was a lot. The family ate for 3 hours before coming to bed for a late night.  Mark, his brother and his uncle all awoke before dawn to the sounds of people working in the back garden.  Mark decided that he better get outside and see what was going on.  He walked outside and saw the family gathered around the small table preparing for the party.  Mark joined the crowd and watched as the family put the food on the plates.  A cup of coffee was being poured out for everyone as well as 2 glasses of juice to keep them going for the rest of the day.  Everyone joined Mark at the table where they were served a cake made by Mark.  Everyone opened a present from each other and a few more gifts were played in the meantime before the cake was cut off.  Everyone ate at their normal time, but only Mark and his uncle could not finish the food.  Mark, his uncle, and his brother took turns taking a piece of cake from each other.  When Mark and his uncle finished, it was time for them to leave.  The family put their gifts in their bags with the few extra candles on top and headed home.  They reached their house at 8:30 sharp, and at 8:45 they finished cleaning up so that they could start the party.  Everyone was dressed in their finest clothes and ready to party so Mark and I got in on the action.  We had a blast celebrating together at my house. We had a great night in and as I said before, we celebrated Mark’s 18th birthday.  He got 2 gifts from us since he is married and that way it was easier for him to open his presents later that night.

A

(c) You had to determine the average score of a round on each of the following golf courses, which ones did you choose? C: golf course A: 7 over golf course B: 7 under golf course
Output: 3
(a) Golf is a sport (but you couldn’t argue it was, because it is a game).(b) It's a game(s) of 10 shots, which means there are 11 shots, because the average golfer is playing with 11 others (who are playing as well).(c) A round-a de de dozen is a hole in one: it is a hole in one and an ace all on the same hole.(d) You had to determine which of these statements corresponds to the golf course, A: golf course B: golf course C: golf course
Output: 4
(a) The length it takes is 10 or 11 holes.(b) As for golf: It's a sport.(c) It's not a game.(d) A round-a (a de de dozen)-one(e) A round-a do de dozen: hole in one(f)

Input:The number of trees that a forest can support is directly proportional to the area of the forest. The more trees there are in a forest, the more trees there are to support.  The trees in a forest support an area of the forest equal to its area. How many trees are in the forest?
Output: 16

Input: The area of a forest depends upon four things:  1. the area of the forest, 2. the forest's height, 3. the forest's density, and 4. the amount of sunlight received.  The tree's area varies with its height.  The tree with the tallest height in the forest has the most area.  The trees with the smallest areas in the forest have the fewest trees.  Thus the area of the forest with the trees which support the most area is equal to the area of the tree.  The trees which support the smallest areas have the fewest trees to support their area.  So the area of the forest which has the fewest trees to control it's area contains the fewest areas.  So the area with the fewest trees has the most to control its area.  The area with the fewest areas has the least control of its area.  So the areas with the fewest trees contain fewer areas.  The areas with the fewest areas have the fewest number of trees to control.  So the areas which contain the fewest trees have the fewest number trees to control.  Thus the areas which contain the least trees contain the fewest tree's to control.  So to control the area of the forest whose trees comprise the fewest number of areas to control, the individual trees must be thinned out so as to control their area.  So it is clear that the area of a forest will depend upon the number of trees to control it.  If a forest is divided into sections, each section will have a corresponding area dependent on the number of trees to be cut out of the forest which constitute its section.  Thus it is clear that the areas of a forest depend upon the number of individual trees to be cut out. If forests are divided into sections, each individual tree is required to be cut out of a section which has a corresponding area dependent on its area. Thus it is clear that areas of a forest are dependent upon the number of individual tree's to be cut out. Sourcream

Salsa
1 C raw diced tomatoes

Vinegar
4 T salt

Pepper

Question 8 is what is called a “scramble for cash” question where a large payment is required.  It is also sometimes referred to as a “shopping cart” problem in which only those payments that can be easily divided up, and with no payment required at all, are included.
The $100 question is a “coupon” question where payments for the whole sum are not required, and the question is often written as a coupon question where some payment is indicated.  It is sometimes called a “money jar” problem where all payments must be paid in advance. It is sometimes also referred to as a ‘tied down’ question.

Question 9 is what is called a task or ‘perk question’ where payment from one person is required of another and the payment is divided up in such a way that no payment is required at the end.
The $150 question is one in which payments are indicated on checks.

Question 10 is what is called a shopping cart problem where all payments are required to be made from one person.
The $100 and $150 question are called “buyer’s dilemma” and “get rich quick” problem questions.  The $100 question is a question where the seller wishes to buy an item, but the buyer wishes to purchase another unrelated item.  The $150 question is a question where there is no single item that the buyer would not like to purchase.
Example A:
The seller writes a check for $100.00 to buy a new car,
The buyer wrote a check for $100 and received the car.

Example B:
The seller writes two checks for $150.00, one of which is for the $150.00 check which was returned with a note that the money must be returned plus $50.00 for a purchase of a car.  The buyer wrote a check for a $2,500 check for the same car.  The check was returned with a note and stated, “We will not reimburse you until you tell us how much to deduct from your check for the check you received.”  The buyer wrote a $3,500 check for the car and received it in the mail.

Feedback on previous lessons :
You are a college physics student and you are learning about magnets.  You have learned that magnetism is the attraction of two objects when they are close together and that the force of attraction (called the attractive force) is equal to the force at rest (at rest is equal to zero).  You learn that an object (like a coin) with magnetism (not to be confused with energy) will attract another object with another form of magnetism (not to confuse with momentum).  You also learn that when two oppositely magnetized objects come near one another they will be attracted to one another.  You have learned to differentiate between mass and force.  (Differentiating mass and force is easy; mass has gravity; force does not.)  You also learned that when two magnets are near each other, the ones nearest to each other will be attracted toward each other.  You learned that the force of attraction is equal to the force of rest.  You also learned that an object with higher magnetism (and therefore higher magnetism minus momentum) will attract and pull things closer together.  You learned that an object with more mass will be drawn away from things with less mass.  You also learned to use statistics to estimate the forces or motions of objects.
